Patch Set 16:

Hi Richard and Sumanth,

Sorry I'm a bit late to the review party here; I've been reading up on the comments so far, but still don't have a clear idea of what the objective behind the dbus implementation is.

I see you've added the text:

> However, D-Bus option is also
> provided to enable certain use-cases like Add-In-Cards. Socket interface
> currently does not provide a way to discover addition of a card, removal of a
> card to upper layers, and thus D-Bus based solution is provided until
> kernel-based socket API has these capabilities.

but can you explain what functionality we're needing to add here? At present, this sounds more like higher-level bus management, not the transfer of MCTP messages themselves.

My concern is that channeling large MCTP messages (eg, firmware update data) is not really suited to dbus - that's one of lessons we learnt from the dbus IPMI implementation. Given the dbus infrastructures is widely used by OpenBMC, dbus performance issues could potentially affect more than just the MCTP subsystem.

Perhaps we need a d-bus control mechanism, with the actual MCTP messages still transferred over the socket?

Also, this change includes a lot of stuff not related to the introduction of a dbus interface (like changing all of "demux" to "de-mux"). Can make this change just about the dbus interface?

Hi Richard,

> We are looking at a implementation where BMC will act as Bus owner in MCTP Over SMBus, which needs to discover add-in-card in dynamic way and assign EID,

OK, the current design is intended to handle all of that, until:

> and expose the same (discovered) to the upper layers like PLDM / SPDM etc.

which sounds good, yes.

> As current socket based mechanism can't support the same, we are looking at the standard way of doing the same (Currently socket based notification of the same is not standard, and don't want to take that approach).

OK, but this still doesn't explain why we need to move the messaging channel from sockets to dbus.

I suspect you mean something like:

  We need to provide out-of-band data about other non-messaging events, which the socket
  interface cannot provide, so we have added a dbus interface for MCTP communication, which 
  can provide extra information about discovered information and bus topology.

Even so, this doesn't preclude using dbus for out-of-band data, rather than moving all MCTP messages to dbus. Or am I missing something here?

> We understand the D-Bus latency, and hence tried to reduce the same, and even designed with multiple instances for each physical medium to reduce the latency.

We would still potentially be channelling large amounts of data over the dbus System bus, no matter how many instances are started.

> As we are adding the D-Bus, we thought of correcting the name to proper one, but we can remove the demux to "de-mux" change

Yes, please do - this is relevant for all changes - you want to be proposing one change only.

Thanks!


Jeremy

Note: Our ultimate goal is to come back to Socket, but we are not going to start with that, considering a standard way for device advertisement etc. Once the MCTP is moved to driver based logic and standard way is defined for socket based advertisement, we will fall back to socket based approach (Note: we are still not going to start with driver based MCTP code). Hi Richard,

> Currently we have file pointer based D-Bus call for handling large amount of data

Not sure I understand - you're proposing to save MCTP large packets in a file, and pass a file pointer to the receiving process? Or passing a file pointer to a FIFO of packet data?

> Note: Our ultimate goal is to come back to Socket, but we are not going to start with that, > considering a standard way for device advertisement etc.

My concern is that you're diverging a lot from a standard approach to passing packets around a system - ie., using sockets.

I do understand your need to notifications of new devices etc, and think that's a good use-case for dbus. However, you haven't yet demonstrated a good rationale for passing actual MCTP messages over dbus instead of sockets.

You're essentially creating a lot of work that will need to be re-done if/when you move to kernel-provided sockets. Unless you have a good reason to do so, I don't agree with this change.

Instead, I suggest you keep to the socket-based approach for messages, and implement out-of-band functionality on dbus. This will give you a very easy transition later.

Our logic is based on multiple instances of daemon (we don't want to run one daemon for all our physical medium interfaces, our plan is to execute one for PCIe and one for SMBus, but both must send / receive MCTP messages with Objects discovered etc, so that upper layer application like PLDM / SPDM will be able to query everything). We also don't want to come & interfere in the socket based structure, as we want to support independent network and Topmost bus owner logic. So, Even the existing socket based implementation itself may require change when we want to implement the socket in a standard way (Currently it is defined as a private structure etc), Any change there will affect all our applications. We are planning to use wrapper library so that when needed the switch can be done in easier form. 

Note: We want to use the libmctp stack, but not planning to use the de-mux daemon, and instead follow the D-Bus daemon path. The upper application like PLDM can have the wrapper layer. Both this approach can co-exist, and we can decide based on practical data.
